Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54143-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
July 2020 
 
 
 
 
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Capacity for 
Multilateral and Regional Economic Integration 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency unit of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar. 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AEC  –  ASEAN Economic Community 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  CEA  –  Critical Element for Accession 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  WTO  –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
Vice-President  Ahmed M. Saeed, Operations 2 
Director General  Ramesh Subramaniam, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Directors  Sunil Mitra, Country Director, Timor-Leste Resident Mission (TLRM), 
SERD  
Jose Antonio R. Tan, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade 
Division (SEPF), SERD  
   
Team leader  Kanya S. Sasradipoera, Senior Trade Specialist, SEPF, SERD 
Team members  Jenamae Dajay-Java, Operations Assistant, SEPF, SERD 
Marie Jessamine T. Mitra, Project Analyst, SEPF, SERD  
Geraldo Moniz Da Silva, Operations Assistant, TLRM, SERD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 15062020174741114402 Generated Date: 09-Jul-2020 15:04:59 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  Timor-Leste  pursue 
economic  integration  into  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  regional 
community and the World Trade Organization (WTO) multilateral trading system. The support will 
be  provided  through  (i)  enhanced  regulatory  compliance  with  ASEAN  and  the  WTO, 
(ii) strengthened institutional capacity, and (iii) promotion of private sector support. The TA is 
included in the country operations business plan for Timor-Leste, 2020–2022 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Timor-Leste aims to diversify its economy. Diversifying from its current reliance on the 
petroleum sector is imperative for Timor-Leste and is a key goal of its Strategic Development Plan, 
2011–2030.2 In 2018, the top two merchandise exports of Timor-Leste were petroleum and coffee, 
which together accounted for about 74% of total exports.3 The oil sector dominates the country’s 
economy and yet oil revenues have limited lifespans. Private investment in the non-oil sector has 
focused on serving demand created by public spending. Private investment in the productive 
economy is needed to generate new sources of income and to create jobs for the country’s 
expanding population. Achieving export growth and diversification is also essential to support 
sustainable economic growth. Policies to expand exports will impact positively on domestic trade 
as well. 
 
3.  Integration as vehicle to diversify the economy. Timor-Leste has a liberal trade policy 
regime. As a least-developed and fragile and conflict-affected country, it will continue to receive 
preferential tariff treatment from major markets. Despite this, the country is still experiencing trade 
deficit and limited investment in potential export sectors. Becoming a member of the WTO and 
the ASEAN will bring trade and investment regulations up to regional and multilateral standards 
and increase the transparency of these regulations. Thus, it will improve the enabling environment 
for business and investment, support domestic and international investment in productive sectors 
and create opportunities for greater engagement in regional value chains. It will also give the 
Government of Timor-Leste greater leverage in the development of multilateral and/or regional 
trade policy directions. 
 
4.  Association of Southeast Asian Nations and World Trade Organization responses 
to the coronavirus disease pandemic. Participation in regional policy coordination has become 
critical  to  mitigate  and  isolate  the  impact  of  the  ongoing  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19) 
pandemic. Both ASEAN and the WTO have been active in undertaking coordination on this matter. 
Two summits—the Special ASEAN Summit on COVID-19 and the Special ASEAN Plus Three 
Summit on COVID-19 (including Japan, the Republic of Korea, and the People’s Republic of 
China)—were quickly convened to agree on the collaboration required to address COVID-19. The 
WTO has also established a dedicated page on its website that provides up-to-the-minute trade-
related information, including relevant notifications by WTO members, the impact the virus has 
had on exports and imports, and how WTO activities have been affected by the pandemic. The 
additional measures decided by ASEAN at the two summits will make their members better 
prepared for future pandemics and minimize disruptions to trade and global value chains. 
 
1  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Timor-Leste, 2020–2022. Manila. The TA first appeared in the 
business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 July 2020. 
2  Government of Timor-Leste. 2011. Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan, 2011–2030. Dili. 
3  Annual  merchandise  trade  matrix  –  detailed  products,  exports  in  thousands  of  United  States  dollars. 
https://unctadstat.unctad.org/wds/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=24738 (accessed 12 April 2020).

2 
Enhanced  participation  of  Timor-Leste  at  ASEAN  and  WTO-related  forums,  and  eventual 
membership  in  ASEAN  and  the  WTO,  will  therefore  help  Timor-Leste  prepare  for  similar 
pandemics. 
 
5.  The  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  and  World  Trade  Organization 
accession processes. The ASEAN commitments are aligned with those of the WTO, although 
the ASEAN goes beyond in its approach to liberalization. Efforts to enhance the regulatory 
environment for ASEAN membership will also be supporting Timor-Leste’s WTO accession. 
ASEAN established the ASEAN Coordinating Council Working Group  Meeting on Timor-Leste’s 
ASEAN membership while WTO established the Working Party for Timor-Leste accession, and 
consultations with both are ongoing.4 However, the accession process will require Timor-Leste to 
demonstrate its capacity to implement new policies and institutional reforms. The cost of such 
adjustments requires investments in obtaining expert advice, upgrading skills, developing new 
systems, and adopting new technology. 
 
6.  Preparation of the private sector for economic integration. Timor-Leste has been 
eager to adopt reforms to strengthen the country’s ability to promote private sector-led growth 
and participate in the global economy.5 Ratification and implementation of the commitments under 
ASEAN and the WTO will signal that Timor-Leste is committed to maintaining liberal policies for 
trade and investment, which can significantly reduce the risk for foreign businesses and lead to 
increased foreign direct investment. However, it is important to ensure that the private sector is 
familiar with the new commitments of Timor-Leste under ASEAN and the WTO and is able to reap 
the associated opportunities. Timor-Leste should also facilitate the private sector’s expansion of 
their international and regional business networks. 
 
7.  Nascent institutional trade policy structure. The institutional structure for developing 
and coordinating trade policy in Timor-Leste is still at a nascent stage and exhibits capacity 
constraints. Addressing trade-related issues and developing an international trade strategy will 
require solid institutional foundations. However, agencies that are nominally responsible for 
international trade policy may have little authority over the policies that are most important to trade. 
With ADB’s support, Timor-Leste conducted a capacity building assessment of ministries involved 
in the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), which addressed funding and TA gaps.6 The Public 
Administrative Reform Program, 2019–2023 provides a pathway for mainstreaming required 
reforms.7  
 
8.  Continuation of ADB’s support during a critical juncture. ADB has been supporting 
Timor-Leste’s preparation for regional integration since 2012.8 This long-standing support has 
earned the government’s trust, which is required for policy advisory work and created momentum 
for  regional  integration  through,  among  others,  the  development  of  Timor-Leste’s  ASEAN 
 
4  Timor-Leste applied for ASEAN membership in March 2011 and WTO membership in April 2015. 
5  The reforms include adoption of electronic data interchange of customs information, development of a national single 
window, preparation of negative lists for investment, and commencement of the first exchange of traffic rights 
memorandum of understanding with Indonesia. 
6  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Capacity for Regional Economic 
Integration. Manila. 
7  The Public Administrative Reform Program is a priority program under the VIII Constitutional Government during 
2019–2023. 
 
8  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Preparing for Regional Economic 
Integration. Manila.

3 
Mobilization  Program9 and  identification  of  Critical  Elements  for  Accession  (CEAs).10 The 
government and ASEAN member states are optimistic about a possible official accession to 
ASEAN by 2021. This, however, presents a challenge for the government in ensuring that gaps 
are addressed to become an ASEAN member state. ADB’s continued support is therefore critical. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Timor-Leste becomes a member of ASEAN 
(footnote 2). The TA will have the following outcome: Timor-Leste’s ability to meet regional 
(ASEAN) and multilateral (WTO) accession requirements improved.11 The TA is also aligned with 
operational priority 7 of ADB’s Strategy 2030 (fostering regional cooperation and integration) by 
promoting  trade  and  investment  opportunities  through  the  implementation  of  regional  and 
multilateral agreements. The TA will also seek to measure the potential impact and benefits of 
longer-term reforms to inform subsequent sovereign or private sector investment.12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Regulatory environment enhanced. Building on the CEA position paper and 
the technical position paper developed under the ongoing TA (footnote 6), this output will 
(i) facilitate deliberations between Timor-Leste and ASEAN member states to identify mutually 
agreed priorities for ASEAN accession, (ii) develop a road map for the country’s technical 
readiness for the AEC with a clear timeline and milestones, and (iii) provide necessary policy and 
technical advice for the implementation of the road map. The road map for technical readiness to 
be developed under this TA will cover a broad range of areas in line with ASEAN commitments. 
Since both ASEAN and the WTO are gender-conscious, this output would also introduce the 
mainstreaming of gender perspective and analysis in the regulatory reforms supported by the 
TA.13 The project will develop a strategy to evaluate the impact of trade reforms on women and 
 
gender  inequalities  prior  to  the  implementation  of  such  reforms.14 The  TA  will  convene 
development partner meetings to coordinate the implementation of the road map.15 The TA will 
 
9  Timor-Leste’s ASEAN Mobilization Program maps the key binding ASEAN agreements across Timor-Leste’s 
government agencies to identify how each line agency corresponds to the ASEAN work program, including an 
indicative list of relevant ASEAN agreements and meetings. 
10 CEA’s focus on issues in ASEAN agreements, which require legally binding commitments on concessional 
arrangements to be extended to ASEAN member states. A technical position paper providing deeper analysis as 
well as recommendations on possible negotiation parameters with ASEAN member states would be developed for 
each of the CEAs. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
12 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
13 In 2017, ASEAN adopted the ASEAN Declaration on the Gender-Responsive Implementation of the ASEAN 
Community Vision 2025 and Sustainable Development Goals. The WTO frames and structures its actions based on 
four objectives: (i) raising awareness on the link between trade and gender, (ii) facilitating WTO members' action on 
trade and gender, (iii) generating new data on the impact of trade on women, and (iv) providing training to government 
officials and women entrepreneurs. 
14 For example, the United Nations Conference and Trade Development methodology toolbox may be used. 
15 Some key development partners of ASEAN have approached the Government of Timor-Leste and ADB about 
possible collaboration to support Timor-Leste’s accession to ASEAN. A meeting of development partners will be 
convened upon finalization of the road map to determine which activities will be funded and/or supported by each 
development partner, and regular meetings will be convened for coordination of the road map implementation.

4 
also coordinate with other relevant ADB programs, such as the TA to Indonesia for cross-border 
trade and cooperation.16 
 
11.  Output 2: Institutional capacity strengthened. The TA will implement the findings of the 
capacity building assessment of ministries involved in the AEC (para. 7). The TA will also conduct 
additional assessments to identify trainings required to support the WTO accession process. 
Activities under this output will help strengthen institutional capacity by equipping the government 
with (i) adequately trained focal points across all line ministries on related legal and regulatory 
reforms, (ii) institutions adequately equipped with resources to actively participate in discussions 
central to the process of regional integration, (iii) professionally trained trade and investment 
experts in the medium to long term, (iv) ASEAN- and WTO-sensitive programming in all line 
ministries, and (v) in-house trainers to train its own government staff on the WTO and/or ASEAN 
engagement. 
 
12.  Output 3: Private sector awareness and readiness on the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations and the World Trade Organization supported. Activities under this output will 
focus on WTO/ASEAN awareness and training for the private sector and/or representatives of 
private  sector  organizations.  The  training  will  help  the  private  sector  to  (i)  formulate  a 
comprehensive understanding of the frameworks of ASEAN and the WTO; (ii) have an in-depth 
understanding of the implications for Timor-Leste following ASEAN accession and in preparation 
for  WTO  accession;  (iii)  identify  support  required  for  the  private  sector  to  avail  itself  of 
opportunities arising from ASEAN and WTO accession; and (iv) facilitate business matchmaking 
between Timor-Leste’s private sector and other countries’ private sectors throughout ASEAN (if 
required).  The  activities  also  aim  to  strengthen  existing  public–private  sector  dialogue  in 
Timor-Leste through the delivery of the planned activities, to the extent possible. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,575,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6) and (ii) $500,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.17 The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, supplies, secretarial 
assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The Regional Integration Directorate of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation will 
be the executing agency.18 It will chair the TA steering committee, with implementing agencies 
and other relevant stakeholders as members. The committee will meet biannually to report on 
and discuss TA outputs. The implementing agencies will be the (i) Ministry of Tourism, Commerce 
and Industry; and (ii) Customs Department, Ministry of Finance. 
 
 
16 ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Indonesia for Cross-Border Trade and Cooperation between 
Indonesia and Timor-Leste. Manila. 
17 Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Japan. 
18 The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation is assigned as the main coordinator for the ASEAN accession 
process as stipulated in Timor-Leste’s Council of Ministers resolution on coordination and resources in the ASEAN 
accession process. The implementing agencies are the main ministries to be involved in key AEC agreements, as 
stipulated in Government Resolution 9/2019 on Reinforcing Coordination and resources in the ASEAN accession 
process.

5 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 29 months from August 2020 to December 2022 
following the signing of the TA agreement between the government and ADB. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or  staff  instructions.  The  TA  will  require  30  person-months  of  international  individual 
consultant inputs and 105 person-months of national consultant inputs.19 To ensure a smooth 
transition, and given that the tasks are a continuation of previous work under the existing TA 
(footnote 6), selected consultants will be engaged through direct contracting. 20  The TA will also 
conduct a midterm review on implementation.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Timor-Leste for Capacity for Multilateral and Regional Economic Integration, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
19 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
20 The following consultant positions will be retained from ADB’s ongoing TA for Capacity for Regional Economic 
Integration (footnote 6): (i) team leader (international), (ii) deputy team leader (national), (iii) trade facilitation program 
manager (national), and (iv) communication and liaison officer (national). Recruitments were carried out competitively 
under the ongoing TA.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Regulatory environment enhanced 
1.1 Develop road map for technical readiness for ASEAN accession (December 2020) 
1.2 Identify areas of synergy between ASEAN technical readiness and WTO preparation in the road map 
(December 2020) 
1.3 Convene meeting of development partners on the implementation of the road map (March 2021) 
1.4 Implement measures in the road map (December 2022) 
 
2.  Institutional capacity strengthened 
2.1 Develop capacity development program for ASEAN (and the WTO for AEC areas) (December 2020) 
2.2 Convene meeting of development partners for institutional capacity building on ASEAN (March 2021) 
2.3 Conduct training on ASEAN (and the WTO for AEC) (December 2022) 
2.4 Develop dissemination plan for the training materials (October 2022) 
2.5 Design and prepare in-house programs and materials for the training on ASEAN (and the WTO for 
AEC) (December 2022)

8  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
3.  Private sector awareness and readiness on ASEAN and WTO supported 
3.1 Conduct public–private dialogue on ASEAN and WTO accession (October 2020) 
3.2 Develop work plan for effective engagement of the private sector in ASEAN and the WTO (February 
2021) 
3.3 Conduct training to the private sector covering the implications of ASEAN and WTO accession 
(December 2022) 
3.4 Convene business event to facilitate networking of Timor-Leste’s private sector with the private 
sectors in ASEAN Member States (December 2022) 
Inputs 
ADB: $1.0 million Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6) 
ADB: $0.5 million (Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund) 
Note: The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, office 
supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, AEC = ASEAN Economic Community, ASEAN = Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations, MFAC = Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation, TA = technical assistance, WTO = World Trade 
Organization. 
a  Government of Timor-Leste. 2011. Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan, 2011–2030. Dili. 
b  ASEAN accession does not require a 100% compliance rate with ASEAN agreements because there will be 
negotiation on the accession modality. However, a higher percentage of compliance would strengthen Timor-Leste’s 
position in the negotiation. Further, since ASEAN requirements are consistent with those of the WTO, compliance 
with ASEAN would also mean compliance with the WTO. 
c  The indicator is a continuation of the one used in ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of 
Timor-Leste for Capacity for Regional Economic Integration. Manila. That TA used a 2015 baseline of 1.6%. 
d  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for Capacity for Regional Economic 
Integration. Manila. One of the indicators of output 2 of that TA (“successful implementation of a program and 
regulatory reforms to meet ASEAN requirements”) is as follows: “Time-bound reform program to achieve compliance 
with binding and nonbinding ASEAN requirements is finalized by June 2016.” This TA aims to develop a road map 
that would be agreed by both Timor-Leste and ASEAN member states and monitored by both parties. 
e  The measures under the road map for technical readiness selected to be financed under the TA. 
f  Trainings in the previous support cover general introduction on ASEAN, while this TA will conduct issues specific 
trainings for ASEAN and/or WTO compliance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
